label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, August 14, 1944
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, regarding the plants he is attempting to grow and the furnishing of the apartment house he and Morris purchased. Sidney continues in his letter to describe a lunch he had with an admiral on a Navy ship and a friend they had come to visit he and Morris.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
August 14, 1944
Dear Gertrude,
I am a gardner of no mean ability. Life had become
from the apartment to the office and return to such a
point that Like all old men I took up a hobby. There
were some old plants around the place that were dying
from lack of water and I started by watering these.
Next I moved them up to the pent house so that it is
resplendent with green. When they become seedy on the
pent house I take them down to what I call my nursery
which is a little walled in court yard next to one of
the ap[a]rtments. It is a sweet little court all walled
in the fl[a]gged with courtstones. The people that live
in the apartment have not used the court so I [a]m taking
it over. I have horrible plants called crotons taht
are just the things for you and I to grow. If you wate[r] 
them they grow like weeds. If you dont water them 
they grow much better than the average plant. No matt[er]
what indiginty they suffer they bear up amazingly well
and reward you with ugly red or striped leaves. I
purchased a great deal of my stock from a women whose
husband had died and she was returning to the mainland.
[Dont get excited she was an island resident.] I pa[i]d [her]
just what the pots cost but Morris told me that I had
been jipped because I c ould have squeezed her until she
howled[,] as she was a widder women. I do not know if I
told you that he went into seond hand store and
started buying a set of china. The man wanted sixty 
dollars. When the argument had finished Morris walked
out of the store with the china and a extra pot for
ten dollars. Now you have not heard me say that the
china w[a] worth the ten dollars, it consisted of an
enormous soup tureen, I had not seen one since grand
father was a child, several platters that would hold
enormous roast beef[s] and yo[u] cannot buy any thing larger
than a sparrow, and a couple of plates that are so
disigned that they are either spaniel bowls or were for
men with moustaches. Today was sunday and we really
had fun. A swim before breakfast, then the most 
delicious breakfast on the porch of the outrigger club
Sliced pinapple, big hunks , scrambled eggs and sausages,
waff[L]es and loads of butter and syrup. Afterwards we
went to the office in our little car signed orders,
shouted into our squak boxes and were generally very busy
until twelve thirty. Sunday afternoon is our own[,] so
we came back[,] went swimming again. Then came to the
apartment house and started working. Morris has contr[o]l
of the inside and was filing the china and peering into
cornerswhile I watered the plants at the entrance, the
narrow strip of grass that seperates the bu[i]l[d]ing from the
street and pruned my plants to a point that they wi[L]l
[End Page 1]
never grow again. In the evening we made tongue sandwhiches
with loads of mayonnaise and lettuce leaves, and drank at 
least a quart of milk apiece.
I was famished because yesterday I went on a ship
and had lucnh with an admiral and I can tell you that
it reminded me of the old days at MiKes. Fruit salad and
ice tea. I could not believe my eyes. You would think
that an admiral would have the most wonderful food in the
world and that you would leve the table satiated. Maybe
he always wants to keep in fighting trim. Personally
I enjoy eating so much that I spend the afternnoon in
a semi somulent state. He also had the habit of talking
so low that you had to spread your ears like an elephants
to even hear him whisper regardless of whether he was saying
anything_worth while. You know there are people like that[,]
Eugene P[a]ynal use to talk so low that one could not bother
to listen to him at all. However you have to listen to an
Admiral as long as you are in the navy. When the war is
over that of course will not be necessary. You may reast
assured that when I came on the ship I saluted everything
the wrong way and failed to salute the things that I should
have. I have a pin to match the earrings I sent you and 
also a pin and a little pair of sea horse earrings. Do
you want me to send them at you APA address or somewhere
in F[R]ance or would you rather have me send them to Rose and
have herx resend them to you[,] because maybe you h[a]ve greater
success in receiving things from her than you do from me.
I sent Landine and Rose, Miss Evans and Bo some pocket books
made out of woven grass that are very smart. I dd not send
you any because I cannot imagine you carrying a grass pocket
book around in that cold climate. It would be lixke an
eskimo with an electric fan.
Leonard Cus[k]ing spent the night with us and said
that Atherton Richard[']s must be crazy because Lenorad told
Atherton that wives were not allowed to come to Honlulu
as he had looked the question up for you. I understand 
that the battle of washington is over and that you can get
houses and laundry done there now without any trouble and
that all the people that were buying houses there last year
as an investment are now stuck withx[t]hem and wish to god
they had never seen or heardf the city. Also that The
good old USA is very gay. Long island, Southhampton,
Newport and a long line of places are gayer than they have
been for years and that it is impossible to rent a house
there. Also all the war workers that have come back from
the battle of Washington sit up and now tell you how the
european war should be run from their seats in the racquet 
club. The strikes are unbelievable. It just seems
impossible that men could strike over such petty things
when other s are being blown to bits on battle fields.
However that is human beings and it is what must expect.
All my love darling.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
